Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 06:26AM - edited Jan 27, 2008 06:27AM by twink o2bu, As a woman who did go through with neoadjuvant chemo I want to chime in here... First of all, I think neoadjuvant chemo is a well accepted practice in treating BC in some cases -- primarily if the tumor is in a difficult location, if the tumor is large and margins are in question or, if the patient wants a lumpetomy option.  I fell into the last category.  I don't know that it's accepted practice to choose neoadjuvant chemotherapy to 'test' the efficacy of the selected chemo as a primary consideration but that may be the case in some areas of the country/world.  The upside is that when it works, it's evident and, in my case, the lumpectomy option was viable (I decided to go with a bilateral/right prophylactic mastectomy).  The downside from my perspective is that it may not work (as in the AC for me) thereby extending the period of time that the cancer is in your body.  My nodes were clinically not involved at Dx -- by palpitation and PET/CT.  By the time I had surgery, I had three involved nodes (micromets).  I assume they were there at Dx but can never be certain that they didn't become involved during the neoadjuvant treatment period.   The biggest challenge I had with neoadjuvant chemo is simply the absence of good data and consistent treatment practices.  For example, the timing of the SNB is a controversial subject -- at Dx or after chemo?  Then, what does it mean from a treatment protocol point of view....  Likewise, the addition of adjuvant chemo in this setting... another area with no data.  It gets a little tough making decisions in the absence of studies.  Anyway, I'm rambling on... sorry.  Just wanted to put my two cents worth in.
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 07:07AM twink wrote: I had a bilateral mast last June. SNB came back negative intraoperatively but showed micromets on the path report.  I agreed to a full ALND on the left side.  My BS felt very strongly that 'sampling' nodes didn't provide sufficient information and still left a strong possibility that missed nodes contained cancer.  I opted to have all potential cancerous nodes removed.  As it turned out, the other 14 removed with the full dissection came back negative.  I'm now going through radiation (which I also didn't plan for) but despite the increased risk of lymphedema, I'd rather throw everything possible at this now than regret not having done everything I could.  The surgeries established a level of risk for lymphedema; the radiation increases the risk but as the onc pointed out... better lymphedema than a more dire alternative. Marian, I'm sorry to hear of your path report.  You must be very tired of all this and very scared of the outcome.  I too had positive nodes after neoadjuvant chemo so understand the dissapointment in the outcome.  As for 'volunteered' nodes I think that's typical since the nodes are throughout the breast tissue.  My SNB also produced an extra, unplanned node (which was positive too).  I've heard good things about Xeloda...I hope it kicks the crap right out of any remaining cancer.  I'll PM you separately as I am thinking about you... t

Hell Yeah!  I didn't have to ask when I went in the day of surgery, it was on their checklist and they simply confirmed that I was still on.  It made a difference, even though I was pretty zoned out already.... pre-traumatic stress I think.  Ask for drugs Beth, if they're not offered.  There's no reason to slug through this trial without help.  Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2007 08:07AM twink wrote: Hi Pearl, I just had my 18th rad tx yesterday.  I have 7 to go, then 5 or 8 boosts (I forgot as soon as I left the building....again).  My skin is doing very well, according to the onc, better than expected. I'm very pink and a little tender, especially under the arm.  I use aloe gel in the morning, immediately following treatment and just before bed.  I also started putting aquaphor in the supraclavical area as the skin is starting to peel. I'm taking curcumin (3X1000mg) daily and think that might have something to do with my skin behaving so well.  Not sure if you can take anything during the trial but here are a few interesting links:  http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2002/10/021008070058.htm http://amos.indiana.edu/library/scripts/curry.html http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T7X-4K3K9G6-M&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=0f9f59b1725e7fa07195513ebc44ccb8 In any case, something is working in my favor, so far.  I can see the light at the end of the tunnel and you will too.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 04:21PM twink wrote: Hi Annie (nice humps BTW) -- BC can recur after a mastectomy because it's impossible to remove all breast tissue.  Skin-sparing (fairly common) and nipple-sparing (less common) mastectomies likely increase the amount of breast tissue left behind following surgery (I have no data on this though).  I suppose if I'd been diagnosed Stage 0 or 1, I would've spent more time weighing the benefits and risks of my treatment options.  As it was, Stage II something, triple negative, 50 years old, I went for all the chemo I could get, the bilateral mastectomy and radiation.  I know the stats don't support my approach (i.e. lumpectomy / rads vs. mastectomy) but, as everybody keeps telling me, I'm not a statistic.  That applies to survival as well as treatment effectiveness. As each new tidbit of info was presented to me along this journey (i.e. you have 3 nodes positive for micro mets), I evaluated the choices presented and went with the most aggressive option.  Here's hopping that I don't have to deal with recurrence but if I do, I won't regret my treatment choices.  I may, on the other hand, regret this glass of wine or the fact that I didn't work out (again) today. Hugs Annie. t

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2008 06:39AM twink wrote: Hi galway, It wouldn't be unusual to not be able to feel a lump since your ability to do so would depend on the location of the lump.  Being able to feel it or not has nothing to do with whether it's a cyst ro something else, so don't worry on that account.  Starting your period early is a risk factor for Breast Cancer but that results from the exposure to estrogen over a longer period of time.  You've only had your period for 15 years and I wouldn't think this risk factor is relevant at this stage in your life.  As for the veins and skin, those things could be hormonal related.. are you premenstrual?  This is so much more likely to turn out to be nothing at all Galway you should try and think on the positive side.  All the odds are on your side for a positive outcome. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 01:53PM twink wrote: Hi Annie, I worry about these same things.  I vacillate...imagining that these tests will save me by identifying early metastatic activity on the one hand, or, worse yet, fail me by missing mets (much like the mammogram failed me).  I had a persistent ache in my lower back / hips which I mentioned to my onc at my last follow-up.  She mentioned a few points that I remind myself of when I start to feel the fear and worry growing...  One:  cancer related pain does not get better without medication or treatment...  if you have a pain or an ache that comes and goes, waxes and wanes, seems to be improving... then it's probably not cancer.  Two: bone mets generally don't present in a joint... if you have achey joints it's probably not cancer.  If you can point to a sharp pain in a bone, away from a joint, then it might be something to worry about.  Having said all of this, I know many of the women here at BCO with bone mets say they had absolutely no symptoms and that the mets showed up on a routine scan.  ... the worry can make you crazy but it does get better Annie. t

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 09:14PM twink wrote: Oh yeah, I meant to comment on the bolus too...  I had 28 regular treatments and 5 boosts to the mastectomy scar on the affected breast (right prophy).  The used a bolus in the breast field (not axilla or supraclavicle) every second treat.  The purpose, as it was explained to me, is to create depth, so that the radiation is administered to the skin beneath the bolus.  In any case, my skin held up very well.
Posts.Title: Rads after mastectomy vs. rads after lumpectomy? otter twink

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 09:06PM twink wrote: When I was first diagnosed a year ago, my nodes weren't palpable and didn't light up on the PET/CT scan.  I went on to have neoadjuvant chemo then a bilateral mastectomy.  The SNB results were negative intraoperatively.  For a couple of weeks I was sure I wouldn't have to do radiation which was a good thing since I'd also opted for immediate reconstruction with silicone implants and Alloderm.  My BS broke the news to me at my first post-mastectomy appointment that all three nodes came back positive for micromets.  He did not however recommend chemo but he did want to take the remaining axillary nodes before making a final recommendation.  All 14 nodes came back negative.  I consulted with my medical onc at the time who said no need for rads, but I asked for a second opinion.  I was referred to a local University hospital breast center and the medical onc there thought I should seriously consider rads and also recommended more chemo.  I went for more chemo and, in the meantime, consulted with a rads onc too.  Needless to say, he also recommended rads.  I went for it despite the fact that there were only three nodes with micromets.  In the neoadjuvant setting without an SNB up front (there are pros and cons for this approach) there's really no way of knowing if there were more nodes involved at the outset.  I feel better having done the radiation therapy, just knowing that I've done all I can at this point.  Now that I'm almost one month out from rads, I can honestly say it wasn't as bad as I expected.  I did just fine with minimal SEs.
Posts.Title: Rads after mastectomy vs. rads after lumpectomy? otter twink

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 09:49PM twink wrote: I recall that 6 months was the magic date for mammos and MRIs following radiation.  Too soon and the results can be affected by the aftermath of radiation.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 09:04PM twink wrote: I packed a bag of goodies based on the recommendations of several women.  I didn't use a single thing, except my favorite sleeping pillow, which was only used on the way home to keep the seatbelt away from my chest.  The drains have little tabs and can be safety pinned to a baggy shirt.  I walked out in the same clothes I walked in in... comfy baggy clothes and flat shoes.  My husband carried my untouched bag in and out.  I was only in overnight and slept most of the time.  Reading, or other time-passing helpers were absolutely not necessary for me.  Just my opinion, but I'd go very light on what you take with you.  A pillow for the seatbelt on the ride home is the only thing I can think of that was helpful (besides the vicodin).  When are you going in Stephanie?

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2007 09:19PM twink wrote: The tumor in my left breast was around 3.5 cm.  I had neoadjuvant chemo -- 4 DD AC and 4 DD Taxotere.  By the time of the mastectomy, the tumor measured <2 mm.  I took the neoadjuvant approach so that I could have a lumpectomy option but decided midway through to go for a bilateral mastectomy.  Still, as Shrink says, it was nice to see the little bugger virtually disappear  as a result of chemo.  Well, okay, maybe she didn't use those words, but ...
Posts.Title: Chemo before Surgery Large Tumor jengrsq shrink

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 04:15AM twink wrote: Hi girls!  I thought I'd jump in to this thread too... I'm almost done with rads (27 of 28 full-field treatments complete today, 5 boosts to follow).  I just wanted to offer a few encouraging words to you at the start of the rads stage of your treatment.  I made it through 22 treatments with little problem.  My skin was pink and a little tender but no blisters or broken skin.  I'm now a little more tender but still no broken skin.  I used Aloe gel religiously 2-4 times daily, organic cocoanut oil in my bath, Aveeno hydrocortisone cream for the itchy collarbone area, and LL Bean long sleeve silk undershirts.  I swear by the Curcumin I've been taking too (3X1000mg daily).  I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (silicone implants and Alloderm) last June.  I didn't know I'd be going through radiation until 3 nodes showed up positive for micromets after my surgery.  I went through 4 DD AC, 4 DD Taxotere before surgery then 4 Carboplatin following surgery.  It'll be almost one year of this stuff by the time I finish on Jan 9th.  I'll drop in periodically and see how you're doing.  Good luck to you all.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 10:47AM - edited Nov 8, 2007 10:49AM by twink I think any taxane (taxol or taxotere) can cause hand foot syndrome which, I think, is generally what's going on with sore feet.  Mine hurt on taxotere, I lost a couple of nails and am still recovering (last Tx was May 24th).  My feet don't hurt any longer but the nails are messed up (growing back normal though).  Also, I've not heard of Neulasta (the WBC shot?) causing mouth sores.  In my case, my mouth was quite sore and I had thrush three times, because of the chemo not the neulasta.  If it's really bad, ask for a prescription of Magic Mouthwash...it numbs the mucuous membrane inside your mouth and clears up the soreness.  Hope you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Chemo Side Effects with Feet and Mouth Sores Dollbaby63 lornasgrandma2000

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 06:28PM twink wrote: I'm one year out and still have stiffness, numbness, aches and pains.  I'm much better than two months out of surgery but I'm not my regular old self by a long shot.  I think I have full range of motion but I'm so stiff and achey I can't tell any more.  I feel worse now than I did pre-surgery.  I'm scheduled for more surgery two weeks from now to 'improve' my reconstruction result.  I hear it gets better.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 08:57PM - edited Mar 10, 2008 08:58PM by twink Annie, My mouth was the worst problem during chemo (besides my eyes, hair, brain, etc).  I used the Biotene because it's gentle but, beware, it doesn't cure/heal inflamed mucuous membrane.  I also used the Biotene toothpaste because I couldn't stand the sharp mint/peppermint on my poor raw mouth and gums.  When I finally did get a prescription for Magic Mouthwash I was so relieved. It numbs the mouth and tongue.  Be careful though, it does not cure Thrush (yeast infection), for that you need a prescription.  Now, keep the dishes where they belong! Be well. T

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 09:39PM - edited Dec 27, 2007 09:42PM by twink The pathology report will tell you whether there is any evidence of cancer in the healthy breast.  If there's a surprise package there, worst case scenario is to proceed with node dissection after the fact.  SNB option is gone once the breast tissue is removed.... the process requires an intact breast and local lymphatic system.  I had a bilateral mastectomy, right breast being prophylactic.  Nodes were not checked on the healthy side and, fortunately, the tissue was cancer free.  Hmm... I suppose that's a matter of perspective too.  What a waste of a perfectly healthy breast.  (sigh)  Actually, I'd do it exactly the same, if I had to do it all over again.  No regrets here (besides being diagnosed in the first place). Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 10:27PM twink wrote: Hi Emma, I did 4 DD AC and 4 DD Taxotere last year.  I didn't notice much of a effect from the AC.  The BS checked me out after my 4th AC and there wasn't much change at all... he described the tumor as 'less dense' at that point but no smaller in diameter.  I decided to proceed with the mastectomy at that point but couldn't get it scheduled until well into the Taxotere cycle so I carried on with Taxotere.  Had my 4 treatments, then surgery.  The tumor was virtually gone at the point of surgery ... it went from around 4 cm to <2 mm.  The Taxotere worked.  Patience.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 02:35PM twink wrote: I had 4 DD AC and 4 DD Taxotere IV infusions, plus all the bloodwork the day of treatment.  I went on to have 4 Carboplatin IV infusions, after the mastectomy and axillary node dissection.  The last 3 infusions were limited to my right arm.  I didn't have any problems.  The chemo nurses checked me out pretty carefully before agreeing that I wouldn't 'need' a port.  In the first clinic, their preference was to have all patients with a port but I resisted.  In the second clinic, the port is only required when the nurses feel the patient's veins will be problematic.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2007 03:37PM twink wrote: I'd suggest you (your Mom) get a copy of the pathology report, read it and research the key elements. Breast cancer is treatable.  It's not a death sentence.  The best approach is to become educated on the subject and make sure the best treatment options are offered.  The type of cancer, grade of the cancer cells, receptors, lymph node status, size of the tumor are all things you should know.  Good luck vanilla.
Posts.Title: How much does grade matter? vanillacupcake AnneW

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2008 06:34PM twink wrote: Good luck to all of you starting radiation today, tomorrow, and the day after.  I had my first boost of five today, then I'll be done!  It does go by quickly girls.  Remember to use the cream or aloe or whatever you've chosen every day even if you don't think you need it.  I'm red, sore and peeling in a few small areas but otherwise, my skin has held up remarkably well.  Most of that will start to heal now that the full field treatments are done.  The boosts take a fraction of the time.  Counting down...4 more to go.  Yay!

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2008 10:50AM twink wrote: I specifically asked the onc about antioxidants as I'd heard one shouldn't take them while undergoing radiation therapy.  She said that, although it's all theoretical, she'd recommend not taking them until Tx is complete.  The theory goes that the antioxidants will potentially undermine the effectiveness of the radiation by working against the process.  I wanted to start D3 during treatment and she asked that I wait.  The other onc specifically asked that I not take Vit E during treatment for the same 'theoretical' reasons.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: my bs surgeon said 3boys4me DoreenF

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 09:20PM twink wrote: Hello Feb Fighters.  I thought I'd just drop in from the Feb (2007) Chemo Cruisers.  You are all roughly where our group was at this time last year and I want you to tell you (from somebody who has beentheredonethat), it won't be too long before this is over and you'll be amazed how quickly most of the SEs pass.  I did 4 DD AC, 4 DD Taxotere, bilateral mastectomy, axillary node dissection, 4 Carboplatin, and 33 radiation treatments.  I think I might hold a record for first time Dx Tx.  At this stage most of you will have lost your hair, we all did before the 3rd treament, most around the 2nd AC.  Mine started coming back before I finished Taxotere on May 24.  The thought of losing my hair was so much worse than when it actually happened.  I actually became quite happy with how quickly I could get ready to go out and not having to shave legs and pits was a nice treat.  When it did start to grow back, several of us developed a light facial peach fuzz, like a newborn's lanugo.  We either shaved it or used facial hair remover and it didn't recur.  I also found the treatments had a cumulative effect, with each one being a little more difficult to handle than the previous one.  I was fortunate to not have nausea problems until the last couple of carboplatins. Several girls in our group had nail problems which started with aching nail beds.  Some lost a few nails or their nails lifted away from the finger.  In some cases, the nails became discolored.  This happened to one woman while on AC but for most of us, the taxane was the problem (Taxol or Taxotere).  One woman found that taping her nails down helped retain the nail.  In my case, one month following the completion of Taxotere, I lost a few toenails, other toenails became very brittle and several finger nails became discolored.  The discoloration ranged from a yechy brownish orange to a black smudge buried in the cente of my nail.   Skin can also peel from the hands and feet (foot hand syndrome) due to the taxane.  I don't know if any of this can be prevented but thought I'd mention it as it seems to be a fairly common experience. Eyes, noses, mouths... mucuous membrane can be affected as you've probably figured out.  Thrush (a white coating on the tongue and throat) can also come up.  My eyes were sooo watery for much of the chemo time.  I had thrush twice.  Magic mouthwash is a prescription that helps with mouth care (but it doesn't cure thrush) and is a little more effective than the biotene (which I also used).  Biotene makes a gentle toothpaste too which seemed to be easier on my sore mouth and gums.  Skin care was important to me as I found my skin became very very dry during chemo.  Lindi Skin makes a line of skin care products especially for chemo and rads patients that I really liked (www.lindiskin.com).  The moisturizer was great as was the balm.  I liked to soak in a tub when I was feeling achey and used an organic coconut oil (Spectrum brand) in the water.  I took Ativan to help me sleep and for a brief period, tried an antidepressant.  Many women in our group found either or both of these types of drugs helped them cope.  It's hard to put up a good fight if you're too tired. Hmmmm... I think I got a little carried away.  You guys sound like you're doing just fine and supporting each other as much as you can.  I hope you develop friendships as strong as our group has.  We had our first little get-together last week in Florida.  Stop by our thread to see what fun we had.  All this just one year later.... hang in there ladies.  We've got your backs.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 06:44PM twink wrote: Hello Feb 2008 girls.  I check in with you periodically just to see how you're making out.  I realized that you should all be coming up to the end of chemo if my calculations are right.  I finished my first two rounds last May 24th.  I know how good it feels to be able to say you've survived the insults of chemo and to know that you've done the best you can to kick cancer's butt.  Congratulations on being done or almost done with chemo! Laurel, I too had mouth problems, especially when I was on Taxotere.  I used the Biotene regularly but eventually had to ask for more help... the Magic Mouthwash did help the general rawness by numbing my tongue, throat and gums.  It didn't help with Thrush though and it sounds like you might be suffering from that.  The most obvious sign is a white coating over your entire tongue.  In any case, that required a different prescription to clear up.  Fluconazole is what my onc had me take and it cleared up my mouth problems within a day or two.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking
